originalTitle: Russian 'pick-up artist' accused of secretly filming women in Ghana
title: Let's Talk About Being Safe and Asking First!
content:
Hello, amazing friends! It's your kid-friendly news reporter from Africa here, bringing you an important story from our beautiful continent, Ghana. Today, we're going to talk about something really important: being safe, respecting others, and always remembering to ask for permission.

A Story from Ghana

Imagine you are playing with your friends, having a super fun time. Maybe you're building a sandcastle, or perhaps you're telling a secret joke. Now, imagine someone came along and started filming you without asking! How would that make you feel? A little surprised? Maybe a little uncomfortable? Well, something like that happened in Ghana. Ghana is a wonderful country in West Africa, known for its friendly people, delicious food, and beautiful fabrics. In Ghana, there's a story about a grown-up man who came from a faraway country called Russia. People are saying that this man secretly filmed some grown-up ladies without asking them first. Taking videos of people, especially in private moments, without their permission is not right. It's a bit like someone taking your toy without asking. It makes people feel sad, upset, and like their privacy wasn't respected.

What is Privacy?

Privacy is a big word, but it means something simple and important. It means having your own space and your own choices about what you share with others. Imagine your bedroom. That's your private space, right? You get to decide who comes in and what happens there. Your body is also your private space. You get to decide who touches you and who takes pictures or videos of you. When someone takes a video of you without asking, especially when you're in a private place or doing something private, they are not respecting your privacy. Everyone, whether they are big or small, has a right to their privacy. This means they get to decide what pictures or videos are taken of them and who sees them. Did you know? Ghana is famous for its delicious Jollof rice! It's a yummy rice dish cooked with tomatoes, spices, and sometimes meat or fish. Yum!

Why Asking for Permission is Super Important

Think about when you want to borrow a friend's crayon. What do you do? You ask, "Can I please borrow your crayon?" And your friend can say "Yes" or "No." It's the same with taking pictures or videos of people. We always need to ask, "Is it okay if I take a picture of you?" or "Can I film you?" If someone says "No," then we must respect that and not take the picture or video. If they say "Yes," then it's okay! Asking for permission shows that you respect the other person and their choices. It makes everyone feel safe and happy. When someone films another person secretly, it means they didn't ask. And that makes the other person feel like their choices don't matter. It can make them feel scared or sad. That's why the people in Ghana are saying this man did something wrong.

Ghana Wants Justice

Ghana is a country that believes in fairness and making sure everyone is treated well. When something like this happens, the people of Ghana want to make sure it's set right. So, the country of Ghana has asked Russia to help. They want Russia to send this man back to Ghana. Why send him back? So that he can talk about what happened and explain his actions. It's like when you accidentally break something, and your parents ask you to talk about it and learn from your mistake. Ghana wants to make sure that people who visit their country respect their rules and their people. Did you know? Russia is the biggest country in the world! It's so big that it crosses two continents: Europe and Asia.

How Countries Work Together

Countries around the world often work together, just like friends help each other. When one country asks another country for help with something important, like bringing someone back to talk about what they did, it's called "extradition." It's a big word, but it just means helping each other make sure everyone follows the rules and stays safe. So, Ghana asked Russia to help send this man back. Now, Russia is thinking about what to do. They will look at all the rules and decide the best way to help their friend, Ghana. This shows that countries care about each other and want to make the world a safer place for everyone.

Your Body, Your Rules!

This story reminds us of some really important lessons for all of us: 1. **Always Ask First:** Before you take a picture or video of someone, always ask them if it's okay. If they say no, that's okay! Find something else to film or photograph. 2. **Respect "No":** If someone says they don't want their picture taken, please respect their decision. Everyone has the right to say "no." 3. **Your Privacy Matters:** Remember, your body and your space are private. You get to decide who sees pictures or videos of you. 4. **Tell a Trusted Adult:** If anyone ever makes you feel uncomfortable, sad, or unsafe, or if they take pictures or videos of you without asking, please tell a trusted adult right away. This could be your mom, dad, teacher, auntie, uncle, or another grown-up you trust. They are there to help you! Did you know? Our eyes can see millions of different colors, but sometimes people see colors differently! It's so important that we all learn to respect each other's privacy and always ask for permission. This helps us all live in a kind, safe, and happy world. Let's all remember to be respectful friends and citizens, both in Africa and all around the globe! Stay safe, keep smiling, and remember to always ask!
summary: Ghana has asked Russia to send back a man who is accused of secretly filming women without their permission, reminding us all about the importance of privacy and always asking for permission.
whyMatters: This story is important because it teaches us that everyone has a right to their privacy, and we must always ask for permission before filming or taking pictures of others, especially grown-ups, to make sure everyone feels safe and respected.

originalTitle: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
title: A Fair Chance for Every Baby! News from Guinea-Bissau
content:
Hello, my super friends! It's your kid-friendly reporter from Africa, ready to share some important news with you. Today, we're going to talk about tiny, brand-new babies and how we can keep them strong and healthy. Our story comes from a beautiful country in Africa called Guinea-Bissau. It's a place with lovely people and lots of sunshine, just like many places you know!

What are we talking about?

We're talking about something very important called health, especially for our smallest friends – new babies. You know how sometimes you get a little sniffle or tummy ache? Well, babies can get sick too, and we want to help them stay super healthy right from the start of their lives.

What is Hepatitis B?

There's a special kind of germ that can make people sick, and it's called Hepatitis B. It's a tricky germ that can make your liver sad. Your liver is a very important part inside your body that helps you digest food and stay healthy. When babies get Hepatitis B, it can make them very, very sick, and sometimes it can even be dangerous. **Did you know?** Your liver is like a superhero organ! It cleans your blood and helps you get energy from your food. We need to keep our livers happy!

A Special Shield for Babies

Good news! We have a special way to protect babies from this Hepatitis B germ. It's like giving them a tiny shield! This shield is a special shot, or medicine, that helps their bodies learn how to fight off the germ. Doctors and nurses know that this special shot is very good and helps lots of babies all over the world stay safe from Hepatitis B. **Did you know?** When you get a shot to protect you from sickness, it's called a vaccine! It teaches your body to be strong against germs, like giving it a superpower!

A Plan to Help, But With a Question

Now, here's where the story gets interesting. Some people had an idea for a special study, like a big test, in Guinea-Bissau. They wanted to give this special Hepatitis B shield-shot to some new babies. But here's the tricky part: they were thinking of giving it to *some* babies, but *not all* of them in the study. They wanted to see what would happen.

Who is the WHO?

There's a very important group in the world called the WHO. That stands for the World Health Organization. Think of them like the biggest, kindest doctors and nurses for the whole world! Their job is to make sure everyone, everywhere, has a chance to be healthy and safe. They give advice to countries and help people understand what's best for health. **Did you know?** The WHO helps millions of people every single day by sharing good health ideas and helping when there are sickness problems in different countries!

What the WHO Said

When the WHO heard about the plan to give the special shield-shot to some babies but not others in Guinea-Bissau, they said, "Wait a minute!" They said it was "not right" and "not fair" to do that. They used a bigger word called "unethical," which means it's not a good or fair way to do things, especially when it comes to helping people. Why did they say it wasn't fair? Because doctors and nurses already know that this special shot *really* helps babies fight Hepatitis B. If we know something helps, then everyone who needs it should get it, right? It's like if you know a friend needs a warm blanket on a cold night, you wouldn't just give it to *some* of your friends and not others who are also cold. Everyone deserves help when we know how to give it!

Why Fairness Matters for Babies

The WHO believes that every single baby, no matter where they live, deserves the best chance to be healthy. If we have a medicine that we know works and keeps babies safe from a serious sickness, then all babies should get that medicine. It's about being fair and making sure everyone has an equal opportunity to start life strong and happy. Think about it: imagine you're playing a game, and everyone should get a turn. It wouldn't be fair if some kids got to play and others didn't, especially if everyone wanted to play and there was enough for everyone. The same is true for health! Every baby deserves a turn at being healthy.

What Happens Next?

Because the WHO spoke up and said this wasn't fair, people are now thinking very carefully about the plan. They want to make sure that any study helps everyone and is fair to all the babies. The most important thing is that all babies in Guinea-Bissau, and all over Africa and the world, get the best care to stay healthy and strong. We hope that everyone will work together to make sure every new baby gets all the help they need to fight off germs like Hepatitis B and grow up big and happy. It's all about making sure every little heart has the best start in life! Thank you for listening, my friends! See you next time for more important news from our amazing continent!
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) said it was not fair to give a special shot that helps prevent a sickness called Hepatitis B to some new babies but not others in a study in Guinea-Bissau, because we already know the shot works to keep babies healthy.
whyMatters: This news is important because it reminds us that every baby deserves a fair chance to be healthy, and if we have good medicine to help them, everyone who needs it should get it.

originalTitle: Iran ready to discuss compromises to reach nuclear deal, minister tells BBC in Tehran
title: Countries Talk Peace: A Special Promise!
content:
Hello, Super Reporters!

Hello, amazing friends! It's me, your friendly news reporter for Africa! Today, we have a very important story about two big countries far away. One country is called Iran, and the other is called America. Imagine them like two grown-up friends who are trying to make a really special promise to each other. It’s like when you promise your friend you will share your toys, or promise your parents you will help clean up. Promises are very important, aren't they? This story is about peace and making sure everyone is safe and happy. Sometimes, grown-ups in different countries talk about big things to keep the world a peaceful place for all children, just like you! We want everyone to be able to play, learn, and grow up healthy.

What is a Big Promise?

Our story is about something called a "nuclear deal" or a "big promise about energy." It sounds like a big word, but let's break it down! Think about electricity. We use electricity for so many things! It powers our lights so we can read our favourite books, it charges our phones so we can talk to our family, and it helps our fridges keep food fresh. Without electricity, many things would be different, right? Did you know? Electricity can come from many places! Sometimes it comes from the big sun, sometimes from fast-moving water, and sometimes from a special kind of rock. This special rock is what we're talking about today! This special rock can make a lot of electricity. A LOT! Like enough to light up many, many homes and schools. This is called "nuclear energy." It's very powerful. When grown-ups talk about a "nuclear deal," they are making a promise to only use this super powerful energy for good things. They promise to use it only to make electricity for homes and hospitals, and never for anything that could hurt anyone.

A Special Kind of Energy!

Imagine you have a super-duper strong tool. You can use this tool to build amazing houses and help people. But if you're not careful, or if you use it in the wrong way, it could cause problems. That's why the promise, this "nuclear deal," is so important. It's about being careful and making sure this very strong energy is only used for good things, like making the world brighter and better for everyone. It's like having a big fire that warms your home, but you must be careful so it doesn't spread. Did you know? The sun is also a giant source of energy! It helps plants grow, keeps us warm, and some special panels can even turn sunlight into electricity for our homes! Many villages in Africa now use solar panels for their lights and radios. So, countries talk together to make sure that this powerful energy is only used for peaceful things. They want to make sure no one builds anything dangerous with it. This helps keep all children, everywhere, safe to play and learn and dream without worries.

Talking Like Friends

In our story, a very important person from Iran, his name is Mr. Majid Takht-Ravanchi (that's a long name, isn't it!), was talking to a reporter lady named Lyse Doucet from the BBC. The BBC is like a big news channel that tells people stories from all over the world, just like our news show! Mr. Majid said something interesting. He said that Iran is ready to talk and make a new promise. He wants to discuss how they can all agree again to use this special energy only for good things. He said they are ready to find ways to make everyone happy and safe. It's like finding a way for everyone to win a game, so no one feels left out. Did you know? When countries talk to each other to solve problems, it's called 'diplomacy'. It's like grown-ups trying to solve a puzzle together, using kind words and listening, instead of fighting. It's like when you and your friend have a disagreement about a toy, and then you both sit down and talk about it. You find a way to share, or take turns, or play a different game together. That's what these big countries are trying to do – talk and find a solution that works for everyone.

Whose Turn Is It?

Then Mr. Majid used a fun saying. He said, "the ball was in America's court." What does that mean? Imagine you are playing a game of catch with a friend. You throw the ball to your friend. Now, it's your friend's turn to throw the ball back, right? You wait for them to make the next move in the game. When Mr. Majid said "the ball was in America's court," he meant it's America's turn to show that they also want to make this special promise work again. It means America needs to take the next step in the conversation. They need to show they are ready to talk and find a good solution with Iran, so they can keep everyone safe together. Did you know? Playing games like catch teaches us about taking turns and working together, just like countries need to do! It also teaches us to listen to each other. Both countries need to work together like a team to make this promise strong and keep it. It's like when you and your friends build a sandcastle together – everyone has to help! If one friend stops helping, the sandcastle might not be as strong. For a big promise like this, everyone needs to keep helping.

Why Promises Are Important Everywhere

Making promises and keeping them is so important, not just for big countries, but for all of us! When we keep our promises, people trust us. When countries keep their promises, it helps keep the world peaceful and safe for everyone. This means children in Africa, and all over the world, can grow up in a happy and safe place. In Africa, we know how important peace is. When there is peace, children can go to school, play outside safely, and their families can work and grow food. When countries work together and keep their promises, it helps to build a better future for everyone, everywhere. It means more schools, more playgrounds, and more happy families who can look after each other. Did you know? The African proverb says, 'If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together.' This means working together is always best for big goals, like world peace and safety! Imagine if everyone kept their promises – wouldn't the world be an even more wonderful place? These two countries, Iran and America, are trying to do just that – make a promise and keep it for a safer world for all of us.

Let's Hope for Peace!

So, our news story today is a hopeful one. It's about countries trying to talk, trying to make a promise, and trying to work together for peace. It's about using powerful energy only for good things, like making electricity for our homes and schools, and never for anything that could cause harm. We hope that Iran and America can talk and agree, so that the world can be a safer, happier place for all children, including all of you, our amazing friends here in Africa. Keep smiling, keep learning, and remember how important promises and peace are!
summary: Two big countries, Iran and America, are trying to make a special promise about using powerful energy only for good things, and Iran says it's now America's turn to show they want to agree and talk.
whyMatters: This is important because when countries make and keep promises about powerful energy, it helps keep everyone safe and peaceful, so children everywhere can learn and play without worry or fear.

originalTitle: The big VAR debate: with, without or change its scope?
title: Fair Play in Football: The Big Special Screen Talk!
content:
Hello, Super Sports Fans!

Hello, super sports fans! Do you love football? Kicking the ball, scoring goals, cheering for your favourite team? Football is amazing! It brings so much joy. Everyone wants to play fair. And everyone wants the game to be fun! Sometimes, during a football game, things happen super fast. A referee is a grown-up who helps everyone follow the rules. But even referees can miss things. Or sometimes it's hard to see if the ball crossed the line. That's why we have something called VAR.

What is VAR?

VAR stands for Video Assistant Referee. It's like a special helper team. They sit in a room with lots of TV screens. They watch the game on these screens. They can play the game back slowly. They can see things from different angles. Think of it like this: if you miss something important, your friend might say, 'Hey, look again!' VAR is like that special friend for the referee.

How VAR Helps (and When it Steps In!)

VAR doesn't help with everything. It only steps in for big, important moments. Like if a goal was scored. Was it a proper goal? Or did someone cheat a little bit? It also looks at penalty kicks. A penalty kick is a very big chance to score. Was the foul inside the box? Was it a foul at all? VAR also checks for red cards. A red card means a player has to leave the game. That's a very serious thing. So, VAR makes sure it's fair. And sometimes, two players look the same. VAR helps make sure the referee gives the card to the right person. Imagine if your teacher gave the wrong person a time-out! VAR helps prevent that. Did you know? Football is played all around the world! It's one of the most popular sports ever. Children and grown-ups love it!

Why Some People Like VAR (More Fair Play!)

Many people think VAR is a super idea. Why? Because it helps make the game more fair. No one wants to lose a game because of a big mistake. If a team scores a goal that wasn't really a goal, that's not fair. VAR tries to fix these big mistakes. It's like having super eyes. It helps the referee get the important decisions right. This makes the game fairer for all the players and all the fans. It helps prevent big arguments too. If everyone knows a special screen helper is watching, maybe there will be fewer unfair things happening. Did you know? The referee in a football game wears a special uniform. They also have a whistle to make sounds and cards to show warnings or send players off!

Why Some People Don't Like VAR (Sometimes it's Slow!)

But not everyone loves VAR. Some people say it makes the game slow. Imagine you are watching a super exciting match. A goal is scored! Everyone jumps up and cheers! But then, the referee stops the game. He waits. He listens to the VAR team. He might even run to a little screen on the side of the field to watch it himself. This can take a few minutes. Sometimes it takes a long time. Those minutes can feel like forever! The cheering stops. Everyone has to wait. Some people say this takes away the fun. They miss the quick, exciting flow of the game. Also, sometimes even with VAR, people still disagree! It's not always super clear, even on a screen. So, it can still be a bit confusing.

What Happened Last Weekend? (No VAR Day!)

Last weekend, something interesting happened. Some very important football games were played in a competition called the FA Cup. But for these games, there was no VAR! No special screen helper team. This meant the referees had to make all the big decisions on their own. Just like in the old days. No re-watching things on a screen. Just their eyes and what they saw live. It was a chance for everyone to see what football feels like without VAR. Was it faster? Was it more fun? Or were there more big mistakes? Did you know? The FA Cup is one of the oldest football competitions in the world! It has been played for many, many years in England.

What Do Grown-Ups Think? (Coaches, Fans, and Experts!)

After these games without VAR, lots of grown-ups started talking. Coaches, who help the players, had ideas. Fans, who cheer for their teams, had ideas too. And experts, who know a lot about football, shared their thoughts. Some said, 'Oh, it was so much better without VAR! The game was faster! More exciting!' They liked the natural flow of the game. Others said, 'No, we need VAR! There were too many big mistakes! It's not fair if the wrong team wins because of a bad call!' They want fairness above all. So, everyone has different ideas. They are all thinking about how to make football the best game it can be. How to make it fair AND fun! Did you know? Football players run many kilometres in one game! Sometimes as much as 10 to 12 kilometres – that's like running to school and back many times!

So, What Should We Do? (Change it or Keep it?)

This is the big question! Should we keep VAR? Or should we take it away completely? Or maybe, can we make VAR better? Some ideas are to make VAR faster. Maybe the special screen helpers can talk to the referee quicker. Or only check things that are super, super clear. The grown-ups are trying to find the best way. They want football to be fair for everyone. They want players to know the rules will be followed. And they want all of us, the fans, to have the most fun cheering for our teams! It's a big discussion. But it's all about making our favourite game even better. So we can all enjoy the magic of football, scoring goals, and playing fair!
summary: Grown-ups are talking about a special TV helper called VAR in football games, wondering if it makes the game fairer or too slow, and what the best way is to keep football fun and fair for everyone.
whyMatters: This is important because everyone who loves football, from players to fans, wants the game to be fair and exciting, and figuring out how technology like VAR helps or changes that is a big discussion.
